TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE , GPE . The respondent Government were represented by PERSON , Director of ORG in ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant was born in PERSON , GPE . DATE he served as a career officer in active service with the NORP armed forces in different parts of the former GPE . In DATE he moved to GPE to serve there .

In DATE the applicant ’s wife , PERSON , whom he had married in DATE in ORG , GPE , his mother - in - law , PERSON PERSON ( born in DATE ) and his son , PERSON ( born in DATE ) , moved to GPE . PERSON and PERSON PERSON currently live in GPE and both hold permanent residence permits .

In DATE the applicant was assigned to the reserves . In DATE he began work as a taxi driver in GPE . His wife also worked as a civilian . The applicant ’s mother - in - law needs taking care of due to her age .
On DATE GPE and GPE concluded a treaty on the withdrawal of NORP troops from NORP territory .
On DATE the applicant was discharged from the NORP naval forces with the rank of senior captain .
In DATE the applicant and his wife applied , unsuccessfully , for a flat near GPE under a NORP aid programme .
On DATE the applicant and his wife applied for residence permits in GPE . On DATE they were issued with temporary DATE residence permits .
On DATE the applicant submitted an application for a flat in GPE under an aid programme run by GPE . The application form was in NORP and contained the words “ ORG for ORG ” in its header .

On the application form , which the applicant signed , it was stated that if his application were to be approved and he were to be allocated a flat under the aid programme , he and his family , before moving to GPE and obtaining registration of residence ( propiska ) , keys to the flat and authorisation to use it ( order ) , must vacate the dwelling at their disposal in GPE , cancel their registration of residence there and not seek to stay in the NORP countries as permanent residents . It further stated that in the future the applicant would be allowed to visit the NORP countries only as a foreign visitor . It stated that he and his family did not own a dwelling in the NORP countries and that they would not seek to acquire ownership of or sell the dwelling at their disposal at that time , and that they had not received and would not receive any payment for vacating their current dwelling . The applicant also confirmed that at the time of signing the application he and his family did not have any other dwelling in GPE . According to the application form participation in the programme was voluntary ; the person signing stated that he was aware that in the event of failure to leave the LOC country within DATE and to settle in the dwelling offered to him within DATE of receipt of the notice offering it to him , he would lose all his rights to the dwelling under the aid programme . He would become the owner of the dwelling allocated to him only after he had resided there permanently for DATE .

According to another form , apparently submitted by the applicant to ORG , CARDINAL of the companies responsible for implementation of the aid programme under a contract with ORG for ORG , the applicant ’s family comprised CARDINAL members – the applicant himself and his wife .

On DATE the applicant requested ORG of ORG ( PERSON ) of GPE to cancel his and his wife ’s registration of residence at ORG maantee CARDINAL in GPE in connection with their move to GPE . On DATE the request was granted .
Under the aid programme , the applicant was allocated a flat at CARDINAL FAC , GPE . On DATE he moved in . On DATE the applicant ’s residence was registered at that address ( he obtained propiska ) .

In DATE the applicant and his wife applied for an extension of their residence permits in GPE . On DATE the Minister of the ORG refused their request . The refusal was based on CARDINAL grounds . Firstly , the applicant had served as a professional member of the armed forces of a foreign country and had retired from that post . That ground applied also to his wife . Secondly , both the applicant and his wife had committed themselves to leaving GPE and had been allocated accommodation abroad within the framework of an international aid programme .

The applicant and his wife submitted a complaint to ORG ( PERSON NORP ) which , by a judgment of DATE , dismissed the complaint . It observed that LAW provided that the residence permits of former professional members of the armed forces of a foreign country and their family members could be extended only in exceptional circumstances . The order by the Minister of the ORG had not provided grounds as to why such an exception did not apply in the case of the applicant and his wife . Nevertheless , ORG found the order to be lawful , since LAW did not in any case permit extension of the residence permits of persons who had committed themselves to leaving GPE and who had been granted accommodation abroad within the framework of an international aid programme . ORG agreed with the Minister of the ORG that that ground for refusing the extension was absolute and did not leave the authorities any discretion .

In an appeal to ORG ( Tallinna GPE ) , the applicant and his wife contested the retroactive application of the provision of LAW refusing extensions of residence permits to persons who had committed themselves to leaving GPE and who had been granted accommodation abroad within the framework of an international aid programme . LAW had not contained the disputed provision at the time when the appellants had participated in the aid programme and been granted accommodation in GPE . The appellants argued that their right to have their legitimate expectations fulfilled had been violated , as had the principle of legal certainty . They also noted that the aid programme had been based on a treaty between GPE and GPE ; GPE had not been a party to the aid programme . The applicant and his wife had not undertaken a commitment to leave GPE vis - à - vis that country .

On DATE ORG upheld the judgment of ORG . ORG held that the principle of legitimate expectation could not extend to preventing the legislator from making any changes to the legislation in force at any point in time . At the time they had decided to take part in the aid programme , the appellants had been aware that on being granted accommodation in GPE they would have to leave GPE . They had consented to settle in GPE and they had been granted a flat in GPE in DATE . The appellants could not have had any legitimate expectation that their residence permits would be extended , as the impugned provision had been introduced into LAW in DATE , that is , before the appellants had submitted their request for extension of their residence permits . ORG agreed with the firstinstance court ’s assessment that the appellants’ right to family life had not been violated .
ORG ( NORP ) refused leave to appeal on DATE .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW ( PERSON seadus ) listed the instances in which a residence permit could not be issued or extended . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) provided that a permit could not be issued or extended if the alien applying for it had served as a professional member of the armed forces of a foreign state , had been assigned to the reserve forces thereof or had retired therefrom . DATE ) provided that residence permits could not be issued or extended either for the spouse and minor children of a person referred to in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) . LAW ) , however , provided that , by way of exception , a temporary residence permit could be issued or extended for the alien concerned if this was not excluded on other grounds under the same provision .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) of LAW provided that a residence permit could not in any case be issued or extended if the person concerned had , inter alia , committed himself or herself to leaving GPE or had been granted accommodation abroad within the framework of an international aid programme . This provision was adopted on DATE and entered into force on DATE . In DATE it was the subject of an amendment which does not appear to be relevant to the present case .

According to the Government , in DATE and DATE the President of GPE and the President of GPE had agreed to undertake a project to provide up to CARDINAL units of housing for NORP military officers demobilised from the NORP countries or elsewhere outside GPE . The Government noted that , as GPE had not been a party to the agreement , they did not have the originals of the documents at their disposal and could not provide them .

The Government submitted to the ORG a copy of the “ NORP Military Officer Resettlement Program – Housing Certificate Program ” ( in LANGUAGE ) and the “ NORP Military Officer Resettlement Program – Housing Construction Program – Information Digest ” ( in NORP and in LANGUAGE ) . These information materials appear to have been handed out by the NORP organisers of the aid programme to the participating NORP officers .

According to the information material , the “ NORP Military Officer Resettlement Program ” had been set up in order to provide CARDINAL units of housing for NORP military officers demobilised mainly from the NORP countries . CARDINAL of the units of housing were to be built , the rest being provided through a housing certificate programme .

In order to take part in the programme , officers had to submit their discharge order , passport , official confirmation of the size and composition of the family , official confirmation of current residence in the NORP countries and a signed application for participation in the programme . The latter included statements to the effect that , upon obtaining housing under the programme , the officer and his family would vacate their present dwelling(s ) in the NORP countries and would not seek permanent residence in any of ORG , and from then on would enter ORG only as foreign visitors . The officers had to declare that they and their families did not own housing in GPE nor would they own , acquire or sell any dwellings in the NORP countries , and would not receive any payments for vacating any dwelling . Officers declared their understanding that if they were found to be eligible to participate in the programme and if all the programme ’s terms and conditions were met , they would receive a suitable flat ( under the housing construction programme ) or financial assistance for the purchase of housing units ( under the housing certificate programme ) .

In order to obtain a registration of residence ( propiska ) for their new flat from the passport office , officers had to present their NORP passport and the NORP passports of all family members along with proof of cancellation of their registration of residence in the NORP countries ( vypiska ) for all members of the family . They had to move in DATE of notification by the NORP social welfare services or the local authorities , failing which their flat could be reassigned .
Participation in the programme was voluntary ; no enrolment fee was required .

After the independence of GPE was restored on DATE , NORP troops remained in the country . Following the dissolution of GPE , GPE assumed jurisdiction over the NORP armed forces . On DATE GPE and GPE concluded a treaty on the withdrawal of NORP troops from GPE and the conditions under which they could reside temporarily in GPE . On DATE , GPE and GPE concluded an agreement concerning social guarantees to the retired military personnel of the armed forces of GPE in GPE . The treaty and the agreement entered into force on DATE , having applied on a provisional basis since DATE , the date on which they had been signed .

Under the terms of the treaty , ORG undertook to withdraw from GPE , by DATE , all military personnel who were in active service with the NORP armed forces . Family members of military personnel in active service who did not have a dwelling in GPE were allowed to remain in GPE for DATE .

The agreement provided that retired military personnel , that is , persons discharged from the army and receiving a pension , and their family members , could apply for residence permits in GPE . ORG could refuse the application for a residence permit on grounds of national security .
